node.description: Ten NFL teams have used the sensor mouthguards for years, but a league official said they also wanted to study research schools with strong football programs.
node.content:
["Alabama and Wisconsin are among a handful of college football teams in which some players are wearing mouthguards that protect the teeth and jaw and also collect data for research on how to prevent severe head injuries, the Associated Press reported.", "Ten NFL teams have been using these sensor mouthguards for a few years, but Jennifer Langton, the NFL's senior vice president of health and safety innovation, said that the league also wanted to collaborate with research schools with strong football programs.", "Experts believe that collecting data on blows to the head via a mouthguard offers a newer perspective compared to equipment like helmet sensors, which have been in use for many years.", "\"We wanted to get inside the helmet and closer to the target of interest,\" NFL Chief Medical Officer Allen Sills said. \"That's where the mouthguard seemed to be a natural choice because it's closest to the brain and allows us to see what the body is actually feeling.\"", "On top of Alabama and Wisconsin, football players from North Carolina and Washington have also adopted the gadgets this season, the AP reported.", "Alabama school officials said that 20 players opted to use the sensor mouthguards.", "\"We really wanted to start with a manageable number that we could effectively do, and then continue to grow if we're getting valuable data and there's still an interest in continuing,\" said Lizzie Elder, a program director and associate professor for Alabama's athletic training program.", "Wisconsin officials didn't specify exactly how many players were using the sensors, but Daniel Cobian, a professor of orthopedics and rehabilitation at the university's school of medicine and public health, said that the equipment was directed toward linemen and tight ends.", "\"We know that linemen sustain not just the potential magnitude but a high volume of head impacts because they play in close contact with other players,\" Cobian said.", "For more reporting from the Associated Press, see below.", "", "
The mouthguards that some college football players are wearing this season have a dual purpose. Not only does the equipment provide the obvious protection for teeth and jaws, it also includes sensors collecting data to help research the best way to prevent serious head injuries. An engineer demonstrates on a player\u2019s mouth mold where the sensor will fit once installed into the mouthguard in Charlottesville, Virginia, on August 17, 2021.
", "Jason Mihalik, a professor in North Carolina's department of exercise and sport science, said about 40 of the Tar Heels have used the sensors and that 30 are actively wearing them at any given time.", "School and league officials credited the designers of the sensors for finding a way to produce the technology on such a small piece of equipment without making it significantly larger or more cumbersome. They say that the mouthguards with the sensors don't look much different from those without them.", "Elder said Alabama's specially designed mouthguards even include the Alabama logo.", "\"It's not like it's a bigger mouthguard, or it's bulkier or more uncomfortable,\" Mihalik said. \"They're pretty much the same form.\"", "Wisconsin nose tackle Keeanu Benton says he started wearing the mouthguards with sensors because he wanted to help provide feedback for the researchers. Benton said the mouthguards initially seemed a little big to him but that he quickly adapted.", "\"It feels just the same now,\" Benton said.", "The mouthguards with the sensors are so similar to a typical mouthguard that school officials occasionally have to remind players to be careful with them.", "\"We've noticed players are pretty hard on their mouthguards,\" said Kimberly Harmon, a professor of family medicine and orthopedics and sports medicine at Washington's school of medicine. \"They stick them in helmets. They chew on them. They don't really mind wearing the mouthguards at all, but we had to educate them a little bit on being nice to their mouthguards.\"", "The sensors collect kinematic data, including impact speed, direction, force, location and severity. NFL officials hope that data can help them figure out how to increase player safety.", "Sills noted that a previous study had engineers looking at every concussion that took place in NFL action over a period of several years. When they noticed concussions repeatedly occurred after players lowered their head to initiate contact, it led to the rule changes penalizing that action.", "Langton said the NFL is considering expanding this study to other universities.", "\"You're increasing the number of observation points,\" Langton said. \"It allows you to make more powerful observations and answer questions quicker than we could if we were using NFL data alone.\"", "", "
